I'm Marianne Rafferty. Now back to "Life, Liberty & Levin."

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: Curt Schilling, were you always a Republican?

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: I think I was. I registered and when I registered in 18, I registered as an independent and I think I was -- and I think to this day, I'm probably more an independent Republican because I think socially, I'm very progressive, but fiscally I'm not.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: Socially your view is be and let be.

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: I don't care who you sleep with. I don't care about any of the other things that I have might -- I have a son on the spectrum and he is one of the greatest human beings you're ever going to meet and he formed the LGBTQ Club in high school. And now as far as I know, he's straight. I don't know, I don't really care, but I've had kids coming into my house for eight years that are gay, that our transgender, that are making the change from boy to girl, girl boy. I don't use pronouns around Grant's friend just because I don't want get in trouble with them but --

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: I use pronouns because I don't know what else to say.

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: And they're the greatest kids in the world, and I keep telling them who you are dating? That's absolutely nothing to do with --

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: But you're not a Republican because of that.

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: You're a Republican why?

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: I'm a Republican because I love competition. I think competition brings out the best in human beings. I think --

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: So this whole notion of centralized government, of uniformity, of redistributing wealth, kind of destroys all those motivations and principles.

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: Well, here's the thing. I'm -- the second you say you're against Obamacare, you're hoping people die according to the media. I want everybody to have healthcare. First of all, let's be clear. No one can -- you can't be denied healthcare.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: Right, you go into -- that's Federal law.

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: You can't be denied -- you keep walking in it -- you cannot be -- you can be denied health insurance, but you can't be denied healthcare. The fact that of the matter is, in capitalism, if we force people to -- under a single-payer government-run healthcare system, then we are going to be telling people who go to medical school to become doctors just how much money they're allowed to make every year and that's that slippery slope. And when has our government ever proven to us that they are fiscally competent?

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: And I have this question for you. When Bernie Sanders talks about government, when Elizabeth Warren talks about government, when all of these people talk about government, can they give us some names? In other words, exactly who's going to the healthcare system? And exactly where do these experts come from? They're not experts. They're people who are in the bureaucracy. They are civil servants. They're members of unions in some cases, some of them have seniority. Do they have expert tests? So basically what these leftists are telling us is that the people in the bureaucracy are smarter, more experienced, more noble than all the plebes out there.

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: But isn't that the message they've been telling us?

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: Yes, but how is that the case?

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: Right, no but they've been making it clear to us as Conservatives that we're deplorable. You're just stupid rednecks and we know better than you so just shut up and let us do what we do.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: But we pay most of the bills.

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: With no background of success in doing anything. The government is never -- that's why capitalism -- private sector has kicked the crap out of the government forever because of the competition.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: Are you happy -- you're Republican. Are you happy with how the Republicans generally conduct themselves in Congress?

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: Why not?

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: No, because I think the Republic -- most of the Republicans in Congress stopped representing me about seven or eight years ago and started representing themselves and running for office the day they got into office.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: Is it because they don't stand for Conservative principles? Is it because they don't fight?

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: They drive up the debt? What is it?

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: All of these things?

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: Yes. The Democrats, when they want something, they don't care. They'll go -- they'll ruin your life. They'll ruin lives. They'll do whatever they need to do to get what they want. We've always been, "Excuse me." "May I, please." "I'm sorry." In the sense that you know, we don't want to play dirty pool because we don't believe that dirty pool is a way to play. But when two groups are competing on a playing field and they're playing by separate rules, it's not a fair game and that's exactly what's happened. The Republican Party -- the Freedom Caucus has more my speed now -- Jim Jordan and the guys --

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: Who are conservative elements.

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: Yes, they're -- that's what a Conservative is. A conservative looks at the Constitution as an ironclad document. It's easy, it's simple, it makes sense and it's perfect.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: What do you of this battle over the budget and the wall and the State of the Union? What do you make of all that?

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: Well, I find it ironic. I don't know if irony is the right word, but a couple years ago, I remember before the election, weren't we all screaming for something different? We don't want a career politician. We want somebody to break the mold. You couldn't break the mold any more than we broke it with the guy we put in there. He's not a politician. This is what it looks like when you put someone who isn't a politician in the Oval Office, which is -- he's a pragmatist. He's a problem solver and that's what he's done. He's put up --

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: Yes, he's very Conservative.

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: He is very Conservative, but he's the first politician in our lifetime that kept his work. That's why I believe -- and Mr. President, if you're watching this show, do not give in. The American people are behind you. Don't give in until the Democrats give you what they were giving each other ten years ago, that $40 million or $50 million for the wall, a billion dollars for the wall. He's standing on principle. He's standing on things that we've never -- we watched eight years. I mean, I suffered in eight years watching the Obama administration do things that are going to take us decades to get out of, but President Trump, I do find it -- I don't know what the word that the media treats -- they hate his guts, obviously. They can't stand him. But they never call him President Trump. You ever notice that? They always call him Donald Trump. You never heard them say Barack Obama. It was President Obama and it's just the little things. I don't get caught up in them, but it's just kind of funny how they do that.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: All right, ladies and gentlemen, don't forget, you can join us most weeknights on Levin TV. Give us a call at 844- LEVIN-TV, 844-LEVIN-TV or go to blazetv.com/mark, that's blazetv.com/mark. We'll be right back.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: Curt Schilling, as a broadcaster -- radio, TV, digital TV -- I actually find sports broadcasters to be even more liberal than the so- called mainstream media and they like to talk about politics all the time. First of all, why is that and why do they like to talk about politics all the time?

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: I don't have an answer for why. I do know and I believe the number is 86, but it might be 88% -- they did a poll on sports writers and 88% of the people in the media -- in sports media are liberal.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: Why is that?

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: Well, I think that it's a byproduct of our education system, first off. Most of them have gone to college and got a degree in Gender Studies or whatever they get degrees in these days and that's what they do. I've got to tell you when I got -- when I realized that, when I was done playing and I looked back on that, I think about these guys that are -- they've got four-year degree from BU and they've got a journalism degree and they're standing in front of a kid who's 21 years old, doesn't speak English from the Dominican and he's making $15 million a year and they're taking home, you know, $1,500.00 a month after tax or whatever and there was some bitterness. You can always see in the writing.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: So you think they're bitter because they see athletes making all this money and they make chump change -- many of them.

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: I don't think that's the sole reason. I think that that's part of it. I've seen that dynamic at work, but I do know that -- I was surprised by that by what you said. There were a lot more liberals in the booth and ESPN was -- I mean, I had people literally come up to me. It's almost like being a member of the underground railway, I guess. They would come up and say "Hey, listen I agree with your political views, so keep it up." Like, no one can hear them say that and it turned out to be true. There were no -- almost no outwardly concert -- except for me at ESPN and they made that end pretty quickly, so ...

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: Could it also be in part, you see a lot of the athletes taking the knee, not all of them, a lot of them taking the knee. You see like at the NFL at the highest levels, they cave to the left and also Conservatives don't use sports to make statements. You know, you just said, you're competitive, you're an athlete. You do your thing. You go home or you do your commercials or whatever you do. Could the problem be that for progressivism, witting or unwitting, whatever the format is, whatever the forum is. Sports -- we're going to devour it with our ideology. That's my sense of this. Whatever is out there, we have got to superimpose and project our ideology.

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: And isn't that what they kind of do is as an -- they chew something up, spit it out move to the next thing. I'll give you a great example. Christine Blasey Ford. When was the last time you heard her name?

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: You're right. I haven't heard --

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: I mean that -- but that was -- she was the linchpin of the Trump administration's nomination of Judge Kavanaugh and it turned out she had nothing and it turned out that all the people involved including Michael Avenatti and the lady in Newark, they were lying about this man. They say they -- and Lindsey Graham was right. I think Lindsey Graham justified his political life in the statement he made at the end of that.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: That was his great ...

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: That was.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: You know that was his great sort of Welch speech.

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: "Have you no decency?"

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: And I try to tell people, and I tell my kids, listen if the left will destroy a man like that to get what they want, nobody's off- limits. Look at what they did to General Flynn. This man served his country honorably for how long. He didn't know -- there was -- it wasn't a misleading --

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: Setup.

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: Right, he was set up and we're going to find out when the Mueller stuff is all done that that -- if we can get the truth, it's going to be stunning.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: Well one of the things we'll be able to get is in that chair, I hope General Flynn, who will for once be able to tell his side of the story. People don't understand that when a prosecutor is holding a legal gun to your head, you're not allowed to speak ...

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: And threatening your family.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: And threatening your son, threatening your family. They have enormous power and in this case, there's really no check and balance.

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: Insider power, yes.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: And as a matter of fact, Congress, even Republicans keep saying we need to protect the prosecutor. No, you need to protect his targets because there's no check and balance right now, he's got enormous power beyond any U.S. Attorney.

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: And when you think about the NSA and you think about Google and all of the social media companies and their invasiveness into our lives, you know, they could go tomorrow and plant whatever they wanted on your computer.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: What do you make of the unmasking of General Flynn, the unmasking of these individuals during the Obama administration? Why aren't we getting to the bottom of that? Why aren't we getting to the bottom of that whole Russia collusion?

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: That's half the challenge. We ask questions we already know the answers to. We are talking about -- we know for a fact the President didn't collude in any fashion with Russia, but Hillary Clinton gave somebody -- that is tied to a Russian, you know, companies access the 20% of our uranium?

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: She gave -- that's right, a state-controlled company and also it is she and the DNC that funneled money through a law firm and so forth to a foreign ex-spy who worked with the Russians.

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: And how is that not the story?

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: Isn't that amazing to you?

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: It's more scary than amazing because it's again -- you know, in many -- I've told you this in many ways, the media can do whatever they want to if they don't like you. They can do whatever they want to if they do like you. They've managed to marginalize me in many ways for things I've never done, but when I think about it, like I said, if General Flynn is not off-limits, if Hillary Clinton can give access to our uranium to the Russians and not be held accountable, then the justice system is broken horribly.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: All right, we'll be right back.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: Curt Schilling, you read a lot of history you said. Military history, in particular. You see what the President of the United States is trying to do with North Korea. It's very, very difficult. He was handed a real bad hand there. He's accused of going soft on Russia, yet he's tougher on Russia than Obama has ever been. I really like what he's doing with China, which has been stealing our technology and is expanding militarily in so many ways. I wish our media would focus on some of that and he's reversed the Obama administration's policy vis a vis Iran, which is a terrorist state that has killed American soldiers, which obviously is building ICBMs not for Tel Aviv, but for Los Angeles. But they're grave threat is -- they are on a grave threat to us, too and yet he's not given a lot of credit for what he's doing in foreign policy, which is essentially Reaganism and they attack Reagan, too and Reagan was very, very successful. What do you make of that?

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: Well the first thing, I think the most obvious issue for me is, I find it stunning that when the President of the United States says "America first," people get offended. That's a dog whistle. Now, when the left says dog whistle, America first. Americans are black, white, yellow, brown, green -- I don't -- they're all colors, all races, all religions. America -- that's what makes us so great. But that seems to offend everybody when he says America first. He is the first President --

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: Why does that offend the left?

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: Well I think because --

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: Do they view us as part of a global community?

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: Oh sure they do. Well, you heard them. I mean, Hillary wanted hemispherical borders.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: Well is this why they don't, at this point now, they want open borders. They don't even talk about national sovereignty. Would they actually have us surrender our form of representation to international organizations?

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: Yes, I think they would. First of all, you can't be a sovereign nation without borders. I mean that's just a simple fact. But I've got to tell you, on the foreign policy side, I think, I was struck by a couple of things. When he was running and he -- when he was interviewing people for his Cabinet, he was talking about people for his Joint Chiefs and I can't remember the General's name. I want to say it was Flynn, but it wasn't. It was somebody else. He said that he came away with an impression of President Trump that he didn't go in with. He said, "A lot of times I view people and their intelligence by the questions they ask rather than the questions they answer, and the questions he asked me were just brilliant," and you know, I'll take his word that they were that. I think he's getting advice from the people in -- his inner circle is smaller than any President in our lifetime.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: But I'll tell you, it's so solid with Bolton and Pompeo, and folks like that. If you don't believe in America first, what do you believe in? America second?

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: If your foreign policy is not America first, what is it? China first? I mean, part of the reason I was so distraught over the eight years of Obama is -- whoever was President this time, hopefully it was a conservative, he was going to have to unravel the kowtowing and the bending and the kissing of butt globally that the administration did, apologizing. I mean, our soldiers are buried on foreign territory all over the world and I don't know of any foreign soldiers that are buried on our ground that helped us get what we got now.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: Some French --

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: There are some French -- yes, there are some French, absolutely. Absolutely, but when you go to the graveyard above Normandy Beach above Utah Beach and you look at the rows and the rows and the rows and you watch French citizens react to World War II veterans which is one of the greatest things I've ever seen in my life, you realize that the media doesn't represent not just American interests but the common man.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: All right, we'll be right back

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: I want to circle back to where we began the program -- the Hall of Fame. For people who don't know, who decides who gets into the Hall of Fame?

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: So there's a Baseball Writers Association, a Sports Writers Association, once you get ten years in, you're qualified to get a Hall of Fame ballot.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: So ten years in as a writer?

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: Yes, as a member of the association, so -- and you don't have to be a baseball writer.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: So you can be an expert on boxing.

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: You could be an expert on anything, but baseball and some of the people that are on there have never watched baseball.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: How many of them are there in this group?

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: I think there's a little over 400 now, this year.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: Is that typical or is it normally 400?

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: Yes, it fluctuates. You lose -- if you don't vote, you lose your ballot and there's rules.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: So how does somebody get on the ballot?

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: You have to play ten or more years in the big leagues and once you get that threshold, five years after you retire, you go on the ballot.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: But that means -- so you go on automatically?

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: How do you qualify to go on there?

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: You have to play ten years in --

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: Just by seniority?

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: Yes, by playing a specific amount of time, yes.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: So every baseball player who's played a certain period of time is on a ballot?

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: Yes, and what happens, if you get less than 5% votes, you're off the next year, which is what happens to the ballots.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: What's the highest percentage you ever got?

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: Fifty-something.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: You know when?

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: I think two years ago because it went down last year.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: So you're like perennial. You keep popping up on their ballot.

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: I do wonder how my percentage is. I haven't won a game or struck out a hitter in ten years and I apparently, I'm getting better and worse.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: Do people tell you, writers tell you what's going on? They must talk to each other?

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: So -- but I don't know, 15 years ago, I was in Tampa Bay and the Hall of Fame voting had come out and I think -- I want to say Nolan Ryan had gotten elected and a writer walked into the clubhouse and said -- and this guy was -- he was an ass. He was a pompous guy. He was the 500- pound guy who tells everybody he was the greatest athlete in the world when he wasn't 500 pounds. He turned out to be a horrible human being. He came in and said, "I didn't vote for a Nolan Ryan." Proud and I said, "What do you mean you didn't vote for Nolan Ryan?" He said, "No, if Don Sutton didn't get in unanimously, Nolan Ryan doesn't deserve." And he wrote a huge article on it. And I said, "So you didn't vote for Nolan Ryan so you could get content because you're too lazy to go out and get it yourself." And you realized that this is -- you're being asked to pass judgment on a career you have no business giving comment on, but anyway. I realized that it was a good lesson because I learned early in my life that they don't vote their conscience. They vote a --

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: There are a lot of other reasons.

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: Right, but for a lot of other thing.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: I want to ask you this, I don't want the public to know this. You haven't complained about this to me at all. I'm the one who keeps bringing it up.

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: I never will.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: Let me ask you this. In your mind, who are the three greatest pitchers in modern baseball history?

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: Greg Maddux is the best pitcher in the history of the game.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: Why?

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: Because what he did when he did it belies logic. I think Randy Johnson, probably the greatest --

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: And you played with him?

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: Yes. Probably the greatest power pitcher.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: Let me tell you, if I were standing at the plate and this guy's up there, what was he? Six nine or something? And his arm's speed, I mean he's like 30 feet --

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: He basically almost brushes your nose when he lets go of the baseball.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: I'd be scared to death.

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: You should be because he flexes --

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: Quasi sidearm, I go, whoa, whoa, whoa.

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: Yes, he's throwing a hundred miles an hour.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: I know and that's a big dude.

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: I got to watch that.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: Honored to watch that and I think Pedro Martinez had one of the greatest runs ever. What he did before that three-year period was -- but I would say Maddux and Johnson and there's Clemens before he did the stuff he did.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: What about Ryan?

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: I think Nolan Ryan was one of the greatest strikeout pitchers of all time. Nolan Ryan was a guy -- his last pitch was 95 miles an hour.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: I mean, that's unbelievable.

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: He was like 79 years old when he threw that.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: Yes, I mean -- I would consider him one of the greats.

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: Yes, I -- yes, okay, that's fair.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: I also consider you one of the greatest.

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: Well, I appreciate that.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: I mean, there's nobody better in the postseason -- nobody.

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: I had two goals when I said -- I'll never and -- I honest to God, my wife and I were laying in bed in 1992, right after my first season in the big leagues and she said to me, "You know, what do you want to happen?" I said, "I want two things. I want to win the Roberto Clemente Award, which is -- because Roberto Clemente is my dad's favorite player and I want to retire having all of the teammates that wore my jersey say, "If I had a game to pitch, win or lose, life or death, I would want him on the mound." In 2001, I won the Roberto Clemente Award which is still the highlight of my career. A quick story, my dad, I went to one game as a fan in my lifetime -- in my lifetime. It was Roberto Clemente's final game in 1972. He doubled off John Madden like for his 3,000th hit and he died in the plane crash not long after. The first time I ever saw my dad cry, but that -- that he meant the world to my dad, so he meant the world to me and I got to meet the Clemente family, which was the greatest thrill of my life.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: You're fascinating.

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: And I want to thank you for coming on the program.

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: It's a pleasure. It's always a pleasure.

utterances.speaker: LEVIN
utterances.utterance: God bless you.

utterances.speaker: SCHILLING
utterances.utterance: God bless you.
